prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following abstract of this manuscript.

Input paragraph: Genes act in concierto with each other in specifico contexts to perform their functions. Determining how these genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions. It has been shown that this insight is critical for developing new therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have helped uncover the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, modern models of the architecture of complex traits predict that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for a joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe that diseases are significantl associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies.

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes act in concierto with each other in specifico contexts to perform their functions. Determining how these genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions. It has been shown that this insight is critical for developing new therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have helped uncover the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, modern models of the architecture of complex traits predict that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for a joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe that diseases are significantl associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies.

response.output: Genes collaborate with one another in specific contexts to carry out their functions. Understanding how these genes impact complex traits necessitates a comprehensive understanding of expression regulation across diverse conditions, which is vital for the development of novel therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have facilitated the discovery of individual gene roles in disease-relevant mechanisms. Nevertheless, contemporary models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, a computational method that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is founded on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns across identical conditions. We observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, with our approach demonstrating accuracy in predicting known drug-disease pairs and elucidating mechanisms of action. Moreover, through a CRISPR screen analyzing lipid regulation, we discovered that functionally important contributors lack associations but are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating clusters of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can provide context to genetic associations and unveil potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies.

response.output:
The field of genetic studies has made significant strides in understanding the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms through transcriptome-wide association studies. However, modern models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease etiology and progression, necessitating a more comprehensive approach to study these intricate relationships. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach designed to fill this gap by mapping genetic associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions, allowing us to contextualize gene-trait associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies.

Our findings demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, validating PhenoPLIER's ability to accurately predict known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lacking associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This underscores the importance of incorporating groups of co-expressed genes for a better understanding of gene expression regulation across different conditions and its impact on complex traits.

In conclusion, our study highlights the value of considering genetic associations through gene expression patterns to uncover disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which is critical for developing new therapies. By contextualizing gene-trait associations using co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER offers a more comprehensive approach that can reveal potential therapeutic targets missed by single-gene strategies, ultimately moving the broader field of functional genomics forward in understanding and treating complex diseases.

response.output: In the field of genetic studies and functional genomics, understanding how genes interact with each other to influence complex traits is a critical challenge. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual genes' roles in disease mechanisms, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. However, the current literature lacks a comprehensive approach to contextualize genetic associations within these complex networks of interaction. In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational method that addresses this gap by mapping gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions, allowing us to contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential therapeutic targets missed by single-gene strategies. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players, lacking associations, were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This method not only enhances our understanding of disease etiology but also opens avenues for drug repurposing and clustering of complex traits, thereby moving the broader field forward.

outputs.text: Genes often collaborate with one another in specific contexts to execute their functions. Understanding how these genes impact complex traits necessitates a comprehensive understanding of expression regulation across diverse conditions, which is crucial for the development of novel therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have been instrumental in unveiling the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, contemporary models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, a computational method that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns under the same conditions. Moreover, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players may lack individual associations but are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating clusters of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can provide context for genetic associations and uncover potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies.

outputs.text: In the realm of functional genomics, understanding how genes interact with each other to influence complex traits is a critical yet challenging endeavor. This knowledge gap is particularly relevant for developing new therapies, as modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology and progression. Although transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes in disease mechanisms, they often overlook the intricate interplay between multiple genes. In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach designed to map gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs while inferring their mechanisms of action. Furthermore, through a CRISPR screen analysis of lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lacking associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, our approach contextualizes genetic associations and reveals potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. This work underscores the importance of considering gene interactions in disease etiology and drug mechanisms, paving the way for more effective therapeutic target identification and drug repurposing strategies.

Understanding how these genes influence complex traits necessitates a comprehensive understanding of expression regulation across various conditions, which is vital for the development of novel therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, contemporary models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions play a pivotal role in disease etiology and progression. In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, a computational method that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Moreover, utilizing a CRISPR screen to examine lipid regulation, we discover that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and unveil potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies.

---
The field of genetic studies has made significant strides in understanding the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms through transcriptome-wide association studies. However, modern models of complex trait architecture suggest that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease etiology and progression, necessitating a more comprehensive approach to study these intricate relationships. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach designed to fill this gap by mapping genetic associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions, allowing us to contextualize gene-trait associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies.

Our findings demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, validating PhenoPLIER's ability to accurately predict known drug-disease pairs and infer mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lacking associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This underscores the importance of incorporating groups of co-expressed genes for a better understanding of gene expression regulation across different conditions and its impact on complex traits.

In conclusion, our study highlights the value of considering genetic associations through gene expression patterns to uncover disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which is critical for developing new therapies. By contextualizing gene-trait associations using co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER offers a more comprehensive approach that can reveal potential therapeutic targets missed by single-gene strategies, ultimately moving the broader field of functional genomics forward in understanding and treating complex diseases.

The revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for a joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. Genes act in concert with each other in specific contexts to perform their functions. Determining how these genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions. It has been shown that this insight is critical for developing new therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have helped uncover the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, modern models of the architecture of complex traits predict that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression.

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, abstract, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: In the field of genetic research, understanding how groups of co-expressed genes influence complex traits is crucial for developing new therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes in disease mechanisms, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions play a significant role in disease origin and progression. To address this gap, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, our approach can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. This work highlights the importance of considering gene interactions in disease mechanisms and offers a novel method for identifying these relationships.

---
Here we present PhenoPLIER, a computational methodology that integrates genetic association data and pharmacological perturbation information into a shared latent representation for collective analysis. This representation is founded on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns under identical conditions. We observe that diseases demonstrate significant associations with gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, and our approach proves to be precise in predicting established drug-disease pairs and elucidating mechanisms of action. Moreover, by employing a CRISPR screen to examine lipid regulation, we discover that functionally vital participants lack direct associations but are prioritized within trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating clusters of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can provide context to genetic associations and unveil potential targets overlooked by single-gene tactics. Genes collaborate with each other in specific contexts to execute their functions. Understanding how these genes impact complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across various conditions, which is pivotal for the development of novel therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have contributed to unraveling the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, contemporary models of the architecture of complex traits suggest that gene-gene interactions play a pivotal role in disease etiology and progression.

outputs.text: In the pursuit of understanding the underlying mechanisms of complex traits and diseases, it is essential to consider not just individual genes but also their collective interactions. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of single genes in disease-relevant mechanisms, modern models suggest that gene-gene interactions significantly contribute to disease etiology. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach designed to address this gap by mapping genetic associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns under the same conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, highlighting PhenoPLIER's accuracy in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, by incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, our approach can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies. This is evident from our analysis using a CRISPR screen to study lipid regulation, where functionally important players lacking direct associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. Ultimately, this work underscores the importance of considering gene expression patterns and interactions for uncovering disease etiology and drug mechanisms, thereby contributing to the broader field of functional genomics and therapeutic target discovery.

outputs.text: The intricate interplay between genes and their expression patterns is fundamental to understanding complex biological processes and diseases. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual genes' roles, the current state of research underscores the importance of gene-gene interactions in disease development and progression. However, a significant gap remains in integrating genetic associations with pharmacological perturbation data to contextualize these complex relationships better. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that addresses this challenge by mapping gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns across the same conditions. We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find functionally important players lacking associations but prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIEER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. This novel methodology not only advances our understanding of expression regulation across different conditions but also holds promise for developing new therapies that consider the complex interactions between genes in specific contexts.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies and functional genomics, understanding how groups of co-expressed genes influence complex traits is pivotal for elucidating disease etiology and identifying potential therapeutic targets. However, current approaches often overlook gene-gene interactions that are critical in disease origin and progression. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach designed to fill this gap by mapping genetic associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This is achieved through the use of modules consisting of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, as evidenced by PhenoPLIER's accuracy in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, a CRISPR screen analysis on lipid regulation revealed that functionally important players lacking associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, our approach can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. This mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions is not only critical for developing new therapies but also paves the way for drug repurposing and clustering of complex traits.

By incorporating cohorts of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIEr can provide context to genetic associations and disclose potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies.

Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Furthermore, our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Notably, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This method not only enhances our understanding of disease etiology but also opens avenues for drug repurposing and the identification of novel therapeutic targets.

This method not only enhances our understanding of disease etiology but also opens avenues for drug repurposing and clustering of complex traits, thereby moving the broader field forward.

outputs.text: The intricate interplay between genes is crucial for understanding complex traits and developing new therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene functions, the role of gene-gene interactions in disease etiology remains largely unexplored. This gap in knowledge is significant as modern models suggest that these interactions play a critical part in disease origin and progression. In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified framework for joint analysis. Our method leverages modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions to contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential therapeutic targets overlooked by single-gene strategies. We demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lacking associations are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This study underscores the importance of considering gene interactions in disease etiology and drug discovery, highlighting the broader significance of our approach in advancing functional genomics and therapeutic target identification.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies, understanding how genes interact with each other to influence complex traits is a significant challenge. The mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions is not only crucial for uncovering disease-relevant mechanisms but also critical for developing new therapies. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on the role of individual genes, modern models predict that gene-gene interactions play a pivotal role in disease origin and progression. Here we present PhenoPLIER, a computational approach designed to fill this gap. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets that may be missed by single-gene strategies. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. The approach accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we found that functionally important players lacking associations were prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. This method not only bridges the gap in understanding gene interactions but also opens avenues for drug repurposing and therapeutic target identification through cluster analysis of complex traits.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetics, understanding how genes interact with each other is crucial for deciphering their roles in complex traits and diseases. While transcriptome-wide association studies have shed light on individual gene functions, there remains a gap in our knowledge regarding the intricate interplay between multiple genes, which is predicted to significantly impact disease development and progression. To bridge this gap, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel computational approach that integrates gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a unified latent representation for joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes exhibiting similar expression patterns across the same conditions, allowing for contextualization of genetic associations and identification of potential targets overlooked by single-gene strategies. Our results demonstrate that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. PhenoPLIER accurately predicts known drug-disease pairs and infers mechanisms of action. Furthermore, we validate our approach using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, revealing that functionally important players, despite lacking associations, are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER. These findings not only enhance our understanding of gene interactions but also pave the way for developing more effective therapies and strategies targeting complex diseases.

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes act in concert with each other in specific contexts to perform their functions. Determining how these genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different conditions. It has been shown that this insight is critical for developing new therapies. Transcriptome-wide association studies have helped uncover the role of individual genes in disease-relevant mechanisms. However, modern models of the architecture of complex traits predict that gene-gene interactions play a crucial role in disease origin and progression. Here we introduce PhenoPLIER, a computational approach that maps gene-trait associations and pharmacological perturbation data into a common latent representation for a joint analysis. This representation is based on modules of genes with similar expression patterns across the same conditions. By incorporating groups of co-expressed genes, PhenoPLIER can contextualize genetic associations and reveal potential targets missed by single-gene strategies. We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and our approach is accurate in predicting known drug-disease pairs and inferring mechanisms of action. Furthermore, using a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation, we find that functionally important players lack associations but are prioritized in trait-associated modules by PhenoPLIER.
